Articles.Content:
SOmething I have been working on. The Phoenix rocket series will be coming out some later. I will be designating part of my stream this week (which will be on sunday at noon EST instead of saturday because I will be at SIEGEcon) to the development of this line. So far, it started as a prototype launcher I was going to use to launch my new heavy Kethosat to the Mun. The result of some tuning and playing with it is this:

To keep part counts low (this model is already at 105), I am using Mobius Rocketworks to make the cluster engines, as it has welded cluster mounts. So far, it is fully re-usable (IF you can make orbit and switch back to the main stage in time). It functions much like the Falcon 9, hence the naming scheme here.

Feedback and ideas for the future appreciated.

Future plans:

perfect subassembly

URM cores

multiple upper and lower stages

prepackaged payload orbiters, etc.

Edited October 10, 2013 by Captain Sierra

Just an update, I did some nominal capacity testing on the model shown above. The launch profile is far from what I want but that rocket pictured can orbit about 20 tons. You want to keep it under that to retain de-orbitability.

Another update. I added another of the double rockomax 32s on it (largest white one), or rather, the equivalent thereof. It didn't really improve anything. by my calculations, the actually nominal capacity of this launcher is 19.22 tons. I have reached teh point where more is not helping, so time to go less and see if there is a happy medium. The of course we can make a Phoenix XII Heavy which will no doubt have a capacity somewhere around 50 tons minimum.

EDIT: I am assuming KSP uses metric tons and on that basis, we are running almost 6.1 more metric tons than a Falcon 9 to LKO. Benchmark ACHIEVED!

Edited October 5, 2013 by Captain Sierra
Hey, your launcher would work awesome for my guppy inspired vessel. She weighs in at 17.14 tons according to MechJeb, so it would be a beautiful fit.

I'll take a look. IN the meanwhile, I will be working on smaller, with the Spartan II and Spartan I as uppers to see if I can improve payload capacity, which I doubt. Afterwards, this thing will get turned into some URMs and subassemblies for a nice launch pack.
Yea, I've been having some difficulties building launch vessels for myself, but now that KW is updated, I can make some very nice ones easily.

So, I dropped it down to a newer, smaller variation for launching lesser payloads. This upper stage lacks the punch required. With a better upper, I could probably get more but I think for a single stack serial rocket, 20 tons is really good (correct me if I am wrong).

The Phoenix IX with the Spartan I upper.

Today, I did some work and am nearing completion of the Phoenix XII Heavy!

Some nominal capacity testing puts the payload limit over 40 tons, pretty good for a non-asparagus lifter with only 2 boosters.

Currently there are issues with flexing as it holds on to the center stage longer than the Phoenix XII and reaches the higher atmosphere where control surfaces are less effective. Also carrying it farther into the gravity turn means less help from gimballing and ultimately, you get a very unstable flight profile and lots of flexing. This is being worked on at the moment.

Today, I did some work and am nearing completion of the Phoenix XII Heavy!

[...]

Some nominal capacity testing puts the payload limit over 40 tons, pretty good for a non-asparagus lifter with only 2 boosters.

Currently there are issues with flexing as it holds on to the center stage longer than the Phoenix XII and reaches the higher atmosphere where control surfaces are less effective. Also carrying it farther into the gravity turn means less help from gimballing and ultimately, you get a very unstable flight profile and lots of flexing. This is being worked on at the moment.

You need an external thrust structure to carry the loads. That's the fancy term of RL, but in KSP it goes as follows: put small cubic struts on both sides of the top of each orange tank. Run struts from the lower parts to them, and from them to the upper parts and the cubic struts above them. Some of them to their corresponding pairs on the other booster for cross-support. The struts will distribute the loads among the parts, instead of the lower parts being much more stressed than the ones on top. That's how I build my huge boosters, and it turns out rock solid. Oh, and something from experience: struts don't affect lag as much as other parts: often you get better FPS due to decreased bending, instead of lower because of the increase in part count. I think I have a pic somewhere:

That just works way better than it should by the looks of it, and it's my way of stabilizing mainsail stacks. Try it!

Rune. Space-tape those suckers good!

Since both struts and the evil cubes are physicsless parts, I believe it. I'll give it a shot, though I forsee difficulties since after booster drop, its serial staging. I do bolt the tanks together, which involves using struts as you show just minus the cubics. All in all, I'll get it working and ready for release. The payload capacity for this thing is much higher than I was expecting for not using a single 2.5m engine.
